titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Mr Montréal came to see me this morning, and told me that Mr Woodward was again very ill with a fever— I had a visit also from Count Jenison-Walworth the Bavarian Chargé d’Affairs, one of those who depart with the French Ambassador— He told me that he and his family had lost their whole fortune, by placing it in public National funds— It had been partly in the French funds, annihilated by the French Revolution—partly in Austrian funds, which the Austrian Government had now nearly reduced to nothing at-all; and finally, the rest in a Swedish loan in Holland, of which for the last three years no interest had been paid, and which now the Swedish Government had declared they would not pay, on account of their quarrel with France— Count Frohberg had told me much the same thing of himself— He was an Alsacian, and had been a page of Louis 16. His father emigrated, and all his Estates were confiscated— He then had entered the Austrian service, and had served in it more than ten years— In 1803. He obtained admission into the Teutonic Order, and soon afterwards a Commandery in it. He is now a subject of Wurtemburg— I dined with the Ladies at the French Ambassadors.— Count St: Julien, Baron Blome, Counts Bussche and Frohberg, Barons Gremp and Maréchal, and the Chevalier Brancia, were there— They are all going except Blome, who told me that he did not know whether he should finally go or stay— Probably the course of Denmark would depend upon that of Sweden, which was not yet definitively settled— Signeul the Swedish Consul at Paris had carried the last Propositions from France to Sweden, inviting the Alliance— That offer was, Finland to the Neva—seven Millions of franks in cash to equip a Corps of 25000 men, and one Million monthly to maintain them. This offer had been rejected by Sweden. She insisted upon neutrality.— But at the same time Löwenhielm here had been pushing to the utmost for War, and Sweden had been urging England for a joint invasion of the island of Sealand, which England had not yet consented to, and probably would not— Perhaps Sweden might be allowed to remain neutral; and in that case Denmark would be so too.— After returning home we paid a visit at the Chevalier Bezerra’s; but neither he nor his Lady was at home— We rode out to Kammenoi-Ostrof; and I walked from the Summer Garden home. Mr Smith dined at Mr Venning’s.

2. I was exempt from visitors all this day— Before dinner I went to Rospini’s, the booksellers, and procured the Post-map of Russia. That of Poland I left for a future occasion— After dinner I rode to Kammenoi-Ostroff, with the Ladies and Charles—and walked home. The state of the world, and particularly of my Country presses heavily upon my Mind.— I wrote to America.

3. Mr Harris called upon me with an English Morning Chronicle of 9. June containing the final appointment of Lord Liverpool as first Lord of the Treasury, with authority to form a Ministry— There is a Vote of the House of Commons against them, but from these re-appointments it is presumable they have now secured a majority in their favour— The convulsive trials of the times must be continued, and relief from these agonizing struggles of mankind is yet remote— Mr Lewis sent me some slips from American Newspapers— There they are just commencing, and there they come home to my Country my kindred and my children. The first Report of the operations of the War in Poland was this day published— Nothing material had occurred since the passage of the Niemen, by the French Troops— I sent to the Minister of Commerce Mr Gourieff to enquire when he could see me; he
appointed to-morrow-noon for me to call at his house— I walked out just before dinner with Charles and returned Mr Harris’s Newspaper— After dinner we paid a visit to Mr Krehmer’s in the Country; but there was nobody at home. I walked from the Petersburg Island home

4. Independence day— And my Son John’s Birth-day— May God preserve him, and make him useful to his Country and his kind! I called according to appointment at noon upon Mr Gourieff, and mentioned to him the complaint addressed to me by Mr Hazard the Consul at Archangel— He said he would enquire into the Circumstances and inform me of the result— He enquired respecting the situation of affairs between the United States and Great-Britain; and spoke with much regret of the prospect of War, between them— I told him I regretted it also exceedingly, and that the American Government had been brought to it with extreme reluctance—but I now saw no reason to hope it could be averted. He mentioned the formation of the new Ministry in England, and spoke in very favourable terms of Lord Liverpool, Mr Vansittart and Mr Rose— But he said they had met with a very heavy loss in Mr Perceval, and that it was greatly to be lamented that Lord Wellesley had not joined them— I called at the (late) Ambassador’s— He told me he had this time for the third time written to demand his Passports— Perhaps they thought it a point of etiquette as Prince Kurakin had three times asked for his, to make him do the same thing— So he had done it. But the difference was that the Prince’s demands were before a declaration of War, and his own now, were after it— He had also written to Count Soltykoff requesting him to send some person to receive the house in the City, and the Country-Seat at Kammenoi-Ostrof (both of which were provided by the Emperor Alexander) The Count had answered that he would see to this; but had received no Instructions upon the subject— The Ambassador said if he was to be detained, he should take lodgings at the Hotel du Nord— He made some remarks upon the publication concerning the War in yesterday’s Gazette, and still considered the positions of the Russian armies as dangerous and very much exposed— But he did not exactly account for the five days, lost by the French after their passage of the river, without attacking any of the Russian Corps— He said that in the positions stated by the publication, the Emperor Napoleon, wherever he might chuse to attack would have two men to one. He said too that there was not upon Earth a General so particular in making his arrangements for the contingency of a defeat— That whenever he went into Battle, you would suppose he reckoned upon nothing but being beaten— His retreat is always secure— He said he saw the plan of the Russians— Their point of defence was a chain of mountains— But those mountains were not insuperable, and to take them they were obliged to abandon all Courland— I paid a visit at Count Frohberg’s lodgings but he was not at home— Called at Mr Woodward’s— He has had a new and violent attack of a fever, but is again better.— I settled with him a matter in which Mr Smith was concerned— After I came home I had a visit from Mr Hall, and Mr R. Willing— In the Evening I walked in the Summer-Gardens, and returning met Count Frohberg and Baron Gremp with Mr Lesseps and all his family, just from a water-party. The Ladies with Mr Smith and Charles went to the French Theatre— French Gazettes stop’d. Charles 3 f 4 1/4 i

5. I had no interruption of visitors this day. After dinner we rode to Chrestofsky Island— I walked home, after a tour round the Botanical Garden— Met successively the Chevalier and Madame Bezerra; Count Lauriston, and the Empress Mother; who left her Carriage and walked on the Boulevard of the Island— I read Sermons 11. and 12 Vol 7. of the English preacher— On Censoriousness, and on Obedience to the Will of God— Read also several Chapters of Watts’s Logic— The second part—Judgment— It is more technical than the first part, and less important precisely for that reason— Mr Smith dined at the Ambassador’s.

6. Count Lauriston, (who is no longer the Ambassador,) Mr: Montréal, Mr Harris and Mr Lewis paid me visits this morning. The Count’s third Application like the two former has been dispatched to the Emperor Alexander— The last advices from whom, were received on Saturday by the Empress-Mother— The Emperor writes her from Vidzy, about 45 Versts North of Swenziany: “your Son is alive and well— All is going on well— We shall fight them; we shall beat them, and “la ruse et la perfidie, will have their reward[”]— The Count informed me that he should this Evening remove from his house to his lodgings at the Hotel du Nord, and should send to me to-morrow the chest of which he had desired me to take charge— He is extremely impatient to be gone, and says they now address their letter to him À Son Excellence, Monsieur le Comte de Lauriston, without so much as an et cetera— He says Prince Bagration has joined the Central army, with his advanced guard; but that both the Russian
wings are very much exposed, and that the Emperor Napoleon never suffers his enemy to commit such faults with impunity— It does not appear however that the Russians have been molested in their retreat, or that they will be prevented from assembling all their forces— Mr Montreal had heard a multitude of rumours circulating among the public, which only manifest the agitation of their feelings— Mr Harris had some apprehensions that if Riga should be besieged it would not hold out more than a fortnight— Mr Lewis had received letters from which it appeared the War between the United States & England was unavoidable— In the Evening the Ladies went to the Theatre— I walked in the Summer-Gardens— The heat is excessive.

7. Mr: Octavius Plummer called upon me— He wishes to return to America, in the Minerva; which is to sail in three or four days. But he has been unable yet to obtain his Passport, though he applied for it some weeks since— The difficulties and delays of obtaining Passports either to come into the Country or to leave it, are always great; and now when they must be procured from the place of the Emperor’s occasional residence they are much increased. I told Mr Plummer that if his Passport did not come in due time I would give him dispatches and ask for a Courier’s Passport for him.— After dinner we rode round upon the Wiburg road, and Kammenoi-Ostrof.— From the new Bridge, building near the Palace, under General Betancourt’s direction, I walked home— Mr Harris, whom I met as I was walking on the quay, left his droshka, and walked with me— We met on the Boulevard of the Admiralty Count Frohberg— His opinion of the state of Affairs at the army, and that of Mr Harris differ very much— The truth may be between the two— The Count said that the Minister of the Police Balacheff had been accompanied by a young illegitimate Count Orloff to the Emperor Napoleon’s Head Quarter’s—he did not know for what— He supposed it might be on account of the Ambassador’s Passports, and those of the other Ministers here who have applied for them— The Count was very anxious to receive his own.— I had the double windows taken out from my Cabinet and Bedchamber.

8. Mr Calhoun, and Captain Seaman called upon me this morning— Captain Seaman to apply for a new Passport— After dinner I walked in the Summer Gardens, and returning, met Count Lauriston, with Mr Lerembours his private Secretary— He told me he had been to Count Soltykoff again to day to apply for his Passports, but that he told him he was perfectly innocent of the detention; that he had received from Head-Quarters not a line of any kind; neither respecting this affair nor any other. The Ambassador said he intended to send in to-morrow a written protest against this refusal to let him go— I met also Count Jennison and Baron Gremp. They are all yet in the same Condition.— This Morning I took a cold Bath in my Chamber

9. A Sailor from the crew of the Monticello, named Charles Drew came to me again this morning, complaining that he had not yet received any part of his wages; and that Mr Sparrow now refused to pay him any— Sparrow wrote me five days ago that he had entirely settled with the whole crew— The further this affair proceeds the worse it looks. I called upon Mr Harris and shewed him Sparrow’s letter, at the same time telling him that Drew still insisted that he had received nothing, and that only one man of the crew had really been paid— Mr Harris shewed me an Account sent him by Sparrow, stating a payment of nearly three thousand Rubles, to these men of the Monticello, for which he says he had taken receipts on stamped paper, and charging Drew, by name with 341 Rubles 46 Copeeks of this Money— I took this Account home with me and shewed it to Drew. The fellow’s astonishment and indignation were inexpressible— He solemnly protested and swore that he had not received a Copeek, and he indulged himself in reflections upon Sparrow and Harris, natural enough upon such an occasion, and which though I did not encourage them, I could not blame— Drew says that Sparrow promised him and the rest of the crew, to pay them, but insisted that they should first ship in vessels bound home— That he Drew, has ship’d accordingly in a vessel bound to New-York, which is to sail in two or three days, and that if he does not get paid he shall lose this chance, and the time that he has already worked on board of her— But Sparrow now refuses the payment, saying he had new Orders from Mr Harris— From Harris’s Conversation with me, I saw evidently enough that since his written promise to me, and the consequent orders he had given to Sparrow, he has really shrunk from his engagement, and limited again Sparrow’s payments— Drew says that he came up here without Sparrow’s knowledge and that Sparrow has repeatedly attempted to prevent him from coming up— Harris avowed to me in the dispute we had on that subject, that he did once give Sparrow orders to that effect— To prevent these People from troubling him and me any more, with their Complaints— By the Laws here, the Captains are personally responsible for the wages of the Seaman, and the foreign Consuls have the summary power of immediately confining them when they refused payment— Mr Harris when first called
upon by the men, says that he forbore to arrest Captain Saul, solely at the request of Mr Cayley an English Merchant, the Agent or Factor of Saul or his owners— And now Saul is sick, and like to die; and he cannot confine him— I told him that Mr Cayley, by requesting him to suspend the exercise of his Official duties, in which the interests of individuals were involved, had made himself, as a Gentleman, in my opinion responsible to him for all the demands, which he had at that request forborne to enforce— And that he himself by the indulgence to Saul, I thought had made himself answerable for the payment of the men’s wages— The whole of this transaction has an aspect which I find it difficult to look at with patience— Drew is only a common Sailor; but he has an intelligence above his condition, and a stubborn perseverance in the pursuit of his right which has been very thoroughly tried, and without which he certainly would have been deprived of it.— I paid a visit to Count St. Julien; who was at home; but sent me an apology for not receiving me. I called on Count Lauriston, at the Hotel du Nord, where he has a good suite of Apartments— I met Count Bussche there— The Ambassador said he had applied to Count Soltykoff to be informed whether he was to consider himself detained as a hostage or as a prisoner— Count Soltykoff had told him that he was perfectly innocent— That he received himself no answers from Head Quarters, not only on this but on any subject.— Talking of the War, Bussche said he had been yesterday to purchase some fusees to make sport for his children— That he had seen a very large board painted with a Fame and Trumpets, and many Military trophies, as a transparency for an illumination— He asked what it was, and was told it had been ordered by the Empress-Mother— Ay! said the Ambassador!—they prepare for illumination before hand— I know they will illuminate, let the Event be what it will— But I shall look the next day after upon the map, to see where the Head-Quarters are; and perhaps they will be at Smolensk— He mentioned, and Mr Harris had told me the same thing before that the Russians expected there would be a great Battle to day; because this was the anniversary of the Battle of Pultawa— It was the anniversary too of the Peace of Tilsit; at which time the Emperor Alexander, said to the Emperor Napoleon; that it was the second time Russia had been saved on that day. Count Lauriston added archly; the Emperor Napoleon laid up this remark, in his Memory—he has not forgotten it; and he probably has not waited for this day.— After I came home I had visits from Mr Slade and Mr Kimball— Mr Slade shewed me a letter from London of 19 June, from which it would appear the British Ministers had concluded to repeal the Orders in Council, conditionally.— After dinner I rode with Catherine and Charles to Kammenoi-Ostrof; and walked home with Charles— Mrs Adams was seized with a violent illness last Night; and the whole of this day was confined to her bed— She was however this Evening much better.

10. I wrote this morning to Count Soltykoff, requesting a Passport as Courier for Mr Octavius Plummer, and received it in the Evening— Mr Plummer was here in the morning, and afterwards Captain Boit who intends going in about three weeks. Etter was also here, to shew me a seal ring which he called an Antique, and which he thought was a Grecian head— I thought it a head of Marcus Aurelius, and no Antique— I shewed him a head of Marcus Aurelius in the Costumes des Anciens Peuples; very strongly resembling that on his ring, which he acknowledged; but he said it would not sell so well for a Roman as for a Greek head. I rode after dinner to Kammenoi-Ostrof, and walked home with Charles— Mrs Adams though better was not well enough to go out.

11. I am forty-five years old— Two thirds of a long life are past, and I have done Nothing to distinguish it by usefulness to my Country, or to Mankind— I have always lived with I hope a suitable sense of my duties in Society, and with a sincere desire to perform them— But Passions, Indolence, weakness and infirmity have sometimes made me swerve from my better knowledge of right, and almost constantly paralyzed my efforts of good— I have no heavy charge upon my Conscience—for which I bless my Maker as well as for all the enjoyments that he has liberally bestowed upon me— I pray for his gracious kindness in future— But it is time to cease forming fruitless Resolutions——Mr E. Plummer visited me this Morning with a Captain Blanchard, just arrived from Riga— And Mr O. Plummer called in the Evening for his Courier’s Passport, which I gave him— Mr Harris was likewise here and brought me the London Morning Chronicles of 17. 18 and 19 June containing the debate on the Revocation of the Orders in Council— I shewed him a letter from his Agent at Cronstadt Sparrow, with an Account of his payments to the Crew of the Monticello, entirely different from that he had sent to Mr Harris, and admitting that he had paid nothing to Drew—but complaining bitterly of him— I am very sure that if it had not been for Drew, not a man of them would ever have received a Ruble— I requested Mr Harris to give Sparrow his Instructions, being unwilling to write Sparrow as I must do, if I answered his letter— Mr Harris promised me that the business should be settled, without any further trouble to me— I know very well that it depends upon him— In the Evening I walked in the Summer Gardens— Met Count Lauriston and Mr St: Genest; walking.
The Chevalier Brancia paid me a visit, and told me that Count Lauriston, and the other allied Ministers had received Passports last Evening; accompanied with notes from Count Soltykoff, observing that as the Military Operations embraced the whole extent of the Western frontiers of the Empire, the Emperor had judged it suitable that they should embark and depart by Sea, for which purpose a public ship would be provided for them; to land them at such Port as they should fix upon— And that they should be furnished with accommodations at the Palace of Oranienbaum, from whence they might embark.— Brancia was deeply exasperated at this treatment, and said he had written to Count Soltykoff, expressing his surprize at it, and demanding a guarantee from the Emperor that he shall not be taken upon his passage by the English, with whom his Sovereign is at War— The Ambassador told me he had done the same thing.— I asked him what they had done with regard to Rayneval— He said that Count Soltykoff had written him, that his Majesty the Emperor having disapproved his having given a Courier’s Passport to Mr Rayneval, he did not know what to say, respecting him.— They will probably not in fact be molested by any English ship of War; but the chances are two to one that they will meet some, and upon English Maritime Principles, their protection will depend altogether upon the English Captain’s Discretion and forbearance.

12. The leisure of the day was employed in writing to America, for Mr Plummer— I had no interruption— After dinner I rode out to Kammenoi-Ostrof, and walked home with Charles— Read Sermons 13 and 14. of the English Preacher Vol. 7. On the Irreligion usually attending on great Riches; by Sherlock; and on the duty of Charity, by Leed— Both very good discourses— The Commentary upon the Parable of the rich Man and Lazarus is ingenious, but whether just or not, may be questioned— Hard heartedness at least as well as irreligion may be inferred from the Narrative as having been the rich Man’s crime— They naturally go hand-in-hand— A man without religion can never have a very strong feeling of humanity—nor can one truly religious be without it.

13. Mr Montreal paid me a morning visit; and Mr Fisher brought me letters he had just received for me from Archangel— They were from my father, mother and brother— The latest, dated 12 April— I was engaged almost the whole day in writing, to send by Mr Plummer— After dinner I rode to Kammenoi-Ostroff and walked home— Our youngest child has been these two days and Nights very sick— I have myself been suffering with a Cold— The French Ambassador called this Evening while we were out.

14. Mr Plummer came for his Passport from me, and for letters; but having concluded not to go before to-morrow morning, he promised to call again. Mr Saltus and Mr Ogden also called upon me— Mr Ogden is likewise going to America; and intends to sail in two or three days— I gave him a despatch for the Secretary of State— Wrote to my brother— Rode out on the Wyburg road, and walked from the Kammenoi-Ostroff Bridge home— The Child is yet very unwell— Dr: Galloway was here this Evening while I was abroad.

15. I went over to the Library and Office for subscription to the St: Petersburg Gazette— Procured a map of Poland, and subscribed for the Gazette; for the last six Months of the present year— Then Called on Count Lauriston at the Hotel du Nord—where I met Count Bussche and Mr Jouffroy— The Ambassador and his family, Mr Lesseps, the French Consul and his Family, Count Frohberg, the Chevalier de Bray, Count Bussche with their Secretaries and families, and the Chevalier Brancia, are to be embarked at Cronstadt, and to go by water to Memel; but Count St: Julien the Austrian Minister, Jouffroy and Colonel Schöler the Prussians, General Pardo, and Count Bose, the Saxon Chargé des Affaires, are permitted to go by land— Rayneval who was stop’d at Mittau, must return here to go by water to Memel. These distinctions are no doubt intended to excite irritations among the allies; but their effect cannot be very extensive— Count Lauriston said he had yesterday written to Count Soltykoff, and received in return from him a Note, saying that the functions and character of French Ambassador having ceased by the Passports furnished him for his departure, Count Soltykoff could hold no further Correspondence with him— There is to be a Frigate, a Corvette, and two Transports which are to be ready on Saturday or Sunday next— The Ambassador as well as Brancia had written to demand a guarantee that they should not be attacked on their passage by the English, to which Count Soltykoff answered that it was to be presumed the Russian Government had taken all necessary precautions, but that they must be sensible he Count Soltykoff could answer them nothing but by the express Command of the Emperor— The Ambassador and Count Bussche were very much exasperated— Jouffroy was tickled with the distinction in his favour, and not very diplomatic to conceal his gratification— I came home and
had a visit from Mr Krabbe the Danish Secretary of Legation— After dinner I rode out on the Kammenoi-Ostrof, and walked home with Charles from the Summer-Garden Bridge— Found Mr O. Plummer, on my return; and gave him my last Letters— The child is yet very ill, with the dysentery.

16. Morning Visit from Captain Boit; and in the Evening from Mr Tilden and Mr Redwood— The weather which has again become very cold, was this day so bad that I did not go out untill the Evening, when I walked to the Chevalier Bezerra’s— He was not at home, but I saw his Lady.— We are in great concern for the child, who continues very ill; but who we hope is this Evening better.

17. Visit this morning from Baron Gremp von Freudenstein, the Secretary of the Wirtemberg legation, who came to mention the packet of papers which Count Frohberg had requested me to take charge of— He is to bring it to morrow-morning— Mr Calhoun and Mr Seamen also called upon me;—I gave Captain Seaman his Passport— After dinner I rode out on the Wyburg road and walked home from the Kammenoi Ostrof Bridge— The Child is yet very unwell, and this Evening Mrs Adams was herself severely ill— I was up untill between one and two in the Morning.

18. Baron Gremp and Mr St: Genest called upon me this morning, and brought with them, the Packages, which the Ambassador and Count Frohberg, had requested me to receive in deposit; being the Archives of the French Embassy, of the former Dutch legation, and of the Wirtemberg Legation— The French are in a very large wooden Chest— The Dutch in a Trunk equally large; and those of Wirtemberg in a small box about the size of a portable writing desk, and covered with Oil-Cloth. In case of my own departure they are to be delivered to Messrs: Livio— I had afterwards visits from Count Lauriston, and Count Bussche, who expect to go down to Oranienbaum on Monday— Count Lauriston asked me if I had seen the Emperor Napoleon’s proclamation to the Army on the commencement of hostilities— I had; but I said there must have been a mistake in the copy or Translation that I saw, which was in English— For it stated the propositions of Russia to have been that the French troops should retire beyond the Rhine, previous to negotiation—whereas it was the Elbe that she had spoken of, and not the Rhine— Lauriston laughed, and said—Oh! the Proclamation est bien de lui—c’est bien là sa manière— My Copy has it the Rhine too . . . but do you know, they did talk about the Rhine. . . Count Romanzoff himself said once to me, that we must retire beyond the Rhine. . . I told him that he must surely mean the Elbe— But he said, [“]mais non, l’Elbe n’est pas votre frontière”— But they mistake one thing for another— Count Romanzoff once complained to me, that the French troops had cross’d the Elbe and the Oder and entered Berlin— They had entered Berlin, but they had not then approached the Oder— But Romanzoff thought they must have crossed the Oder to get to Berlin— But said I, it was the Elbe, and not the Rhine that Prince Kurakin’s Note required you to pass, previous to negotiation was it not?— Yes!— Mais qu’est-ce, qu’il coute a l’Empereur Napoleon de dire que c’etoit le Rhin.”— Lauriston has the same idea of Napoleon’s veracity that Caulaincourt had— Though he is a more enthusiastic admirer of him, and apparently more unbounded in his devotion to him— Count Bussche told me that St: Julien, lingered about going away— That Russia was still courting Austria— That Count Stakelberg the Russian Minister had obtained permission to remain at Vienna, and it had here been indirectly signified to St: Julien, that he might stay here, if it suited his convenience— Even Yesterday St: Julien told Bussche, that it might be some time before he should go— But this morning Berks had called on him (Bussche) and told him St: Julien would positively go on Tuesday; and Lauriston this morning told Bussche the same thing— Whence Bussche concluded that Lauriston had given St: Julien a touch of the spur. General Pardo, and Count Bose are gone.— Mr Raimbert paid me a visit likewise; and mentioned the report of an action in which Prince Bagration has suffered considerable loss, and the French were said to have entered Minsk— Mr Ogden called upon me, and was going immediately to Cronstadt to embark— I received a packet of letters and duplicate pamphlet from Mr George Joy in London— The Ladies went in the Evening to the Theatre. I went to Kammenoi-Ostroff with Charles, and we walked in Count Strogonoff’s Garden, and afterwards in the Summer-garden and home— Met Count Lauriston and Mr St: Genest, on the Quay as we were returning— The Child is better, but yet very unwell.

19. The Chevalier Brancia called upon me this Morning to take leave; he then intended to go down to Oranienbaum this Evening, to be ready to embark— There is a frigate— A Corvette and two Transports— The Ambassador, with Madame Lesseps and her children, go in the frigate— Count Bussche and his family in the Corvette— The other Ministers and the Baggage go in the Transports— Mr Fisher was here also, and asked leave to bring and introduce to me, a Captain Hillard, who comes upon some
business concerning which Mr Hazard has repeatedly written to me— It is one of the rotten cases of fraudulent American papers and Colours— I agreed however to see the Captain— In the Evening, Mr and Madame Bezerra, Count Lauriston and Mr Harris were successively here, from the time when we rose from dinner untill eleven at Night.— The Ambassador came to take leave— Mr Bezerra is low spirited and nervous— The weather and visitors detained me at home the whole day— I read only the Sermons 15 and 16. Vol 7. of the English Preacher— On the wretchedness of a wavering Mind—and on Christ’s Kingdom being not of this World— The former by Atterbury, on the text “Unstable as Water, thou shalt not excel.”— In this discourse I was disappointed; and think the Bishop has not done full Justice to the text.

20. Mr Fisher came with Captain Hillard this morning; the Captain was much dissatisfied that I refused to lend my aid officially to deceive the Russian Government, and prevail upon them to deliver up a ship seized for a breach of their laws and liable to confiscation— The case stands thus upon the Papers sent me by Mr Hazard with the request for my interposition— In September 1809. John Thomas a merchant of Baltimore, made over to one Worthy, of Liverpool in Great-Britain a ship called the Thomas, owned by him, and a Sea-letter ship.— But instead of giving Worthy a Bill of Sale, he gives him a power of Attorney irrevocable to dispose of her, and makes Worthy Supercargo— The ship goes then to Madeira, and returns to New-York in January 1810— In February she sails, for Archangel, taking St. Michael’s and Madeira in her way— Worthy purchases at New-York, of Noah Talcott, a Cargo, as the Agent, and as for account of John Thomas, but pays Talcott, by bills of Exchange upon the House of M’Surr, M’and M’Corksdale of Liverpool. Worthy comes from New-York to Archangel, as Supercargo, and with a Passport, as a Citizen of the United States, (real or forged in the name of De Witt Clinton, Mayor of New-York) The Ship enters at Archangel, as an American in the name of John Thomas, with Worthy, as a Citizen of the United States, for her Supercargo— She was admitted as an American; sold her Cargo; took in a Cargo as if to return and sailed in the Autumn of 1810. But being driven back by the weather, wintered in Archangel; and before she could sail in 1811— was seized, by the Russian Government, upon information lodged by a Sailor that the property and the Voyage, was really for account of the House in Liverpool, and that the ship was bound thither from Archangel, and not to New-York. While the ship was under seizure, Worthy’s bills in favour of Talcott were returned from Liverpool to New-York, protested— Talcott sent to Archangel, and got the ship mortgaged to him by Worthy, for security, and afterwards got a Bill of sale of her in form from John Thomas at Baltimore— And now sends out Captain Hillard, with a Crew, on the expectation of having her restored, to take charge of her, and carry her to New-York— Mr Harris had pursued the claim of this ship last Summer, and now continued it, considering the property, and Worthy himself as american—and he had also claimed very heavy damages for her detention— But the Commission for neutral Navigation, not manifesting a disposition to restore the ship; Mr Hazard wrote to me and sent me the papers with a suggestion that nothing but my interference could get the ship released this year— On the face of the papers Worthy appeared in the double capacity of a British Subject, owner of the ship, and of an American Citizen, Supercargo, for John Thomas— There was a notarial declaration and Certificate that Talcott was a native American, and the same of John Thomas, with his Declaration that he was heretofore sole owner of the ship, and that she sailed with a Certificate in lieu of Register in 1809. The papers all concurred to shew that the property and the Voyage were on British Account, and that John Thomas gave only the cover of his name— Mr Harris shewed me the sentence of the Commission of Neutral Navigation here by which it appears that since the seizure both Worthy and the Captain ran away from Archangel, and that among Worthy’s papers were found letters to him from his wife and from the House at Liverpool, proving their interest in this ship and in another, which Worthy dispatched from Archangel, under American Colours— I declined interfering at all in the Case; and have received three letters from Mr Hazard, on the subject.— The Captain asked me to give my refusal, in writing—which I told him I had already done to Mr Hazard— He said too that Mr Harris told him, that if he had not applied to me, he would before this have had the ship— He complained that Mr Hazard had been three Post-days, without receiving my answer to his first letter— He gave another example of what I have before more than once remarked, that men who ask dishonest favours are apt to be insolent upon finding them refused— I gave him the papers on his promise to be answerable for them, and on Mr Fisher’s answering for him— And I dismissed him with little Ceremony.— Count Frohberg called, and took leave. I gave him at his request a receipt for the packet he has deposited with me— In the Evening we rode out six Wersts on the Moscow road, and on returning, I walked about seven, home.

21. I received from Count Jenison-Walworth, a note with a Trunk, containing the Archives of the Bavarian Legation, and gave a receipt for them, at his desire— So that there are now deposited with me all the Papers of the French, the former Dutch, the Bavarian, Wirtemberg and Westphalian Legations— And in case of my own departure before they are duly called for, I am to leave them all with Messrs: Livio, Bankers. I had visits from Mr Lewis and Mr Redwood, and from Mr Woodward— The merchants are all extremely anxious, concerning the political State of Affairs. Woodward consulted me about the house to which the affairs of Mr Gray in the hands of the Raimbert’s are to be transferred— They expect to be obliged to leave the Country. I had also a visit from Mr Hochschild, who was formerly here as one of Count Stedingk’s Secretaries— He arrived last Night, and comes now as Swedish Chargé des Affaires in the absence of Count Löwenhielm & Mr Brandel— Mr Harris likewise called upon me— The Ladies went to the Theatre— I rode out with Charles on the Peterhoff road to the Narishkin Garden, formerly called Aha! three Wersts without the gate— I had not seen it for thirty years; but recognized in it many of the walks and buildings I had met there before— We returned to the Theatre for the Ladies, and were five minutes too late— We took them up, opposite the Cazan Church— I walked to the Summer Gardens and home. Mr Kimball was here at tea.

22. Morning visit from Mr Montreal— A new Ordinance of the Emperor, concerning foreigners, and particularly frenchmen, has spread a general alarm, and in its terms is so extremely rigorous, that it has been thought necessary to send to the Emperor for an explanation of its extent. Mr Raimbert went yesterday to the military Governor Wiesmitinoff to ascertain what was intended— The Governor received him politely, and told him he was waiting for orders; but at all Events that he should make himself easy— There could be no danger for him.— There is a new levy of five men to every five hundred in the four bordering Governments, and a call for money, and supplies of grain from others— My Coachman was this morning taken for a soldier; but in the Evening was released again, upon payment of 25 Rubles by his Master. The official news from the armies, is all favourable, and according to the hand-bills they have had nothing but a series of Successes from the first day of the campaign— But the Emperor with one army has been retreating from the Niemen River to the Dwina, and is completely separated from the second army under Prince Bagration— He has burnt and destroyed all the towns on his retreat; as well as all the grass and grain standing on the fields; and he must now be compelled to retreat still further, or to give Battle, with only a part of his forces, contrary to what has been officially declared to be his plan. There is great anxiety here, but as yet no symptoms of discouragement— Rumours of disasters both to Prince Bagration’s Army, and to that of the Emperor himself are circulating in whispers, but without any mention of particulars— This Evening I rode out on the Wyburg road, and returned through Kammenoi-Ostroff— We met the Empress and Princess Amelia, riding— I walked, from General Betancourt’s Bridge, home—

23. Captain Russell, of the Justina, a vessel just arrived from New-York, called on me to mention that he had a packet of books, for me— They were sent by a Dr: Ricketson, a Quaker of New-York, and are chiefly intended for the Emperor, to whom the Doctor has enclosed to my care a letter, directed “Alexander I Emperor of Russia. Petersburgh— With Packet of Books.[”] And on the other side “Care of John Quincy Adams, Envoy at Petersburgh— Pr Justine, Captn: Russel.”— The Doctor in his letter to me, asks many questions, concerning Science and particularly Medical concerns; and requests me to give in personal Conversation, just ideas to the Emperor, about the Society of Friends— By the same vessel A Mr John H. Eddy, sends me a map, of the projected Canal for connecting Hudson river with the Lakes of Canada, taken by himself; bound in red Morocco, and covered partly with a paper, directed “For the Emperor Alexander”— He also sends me one, “in plain binding” for myself; with two pamphlets containing the Report of the New-York Commissioners on this subject to the Legislature of the State, and one anonymous pamphlet concerning the same project.— Dr Ricketson and Mr Eddy are so totally strangers to me that I knew not of their existence until I received their letters.— Mr Willing, Mr Tilden, and a Mr Gibson, newly arrived from Boston, also paid me Morning visits.— Mrs Krehmer and Miss Duroveray paid visits to the Ladies— Mrs Duroveray is going to England, and came to take leave— In the Evening I rode to Kammenoi-Ostrof and walked
home— On my return I found Mr Kimball, on an Evening visit.— The French Ambassador, with Counts Frohberg, Bussche, and Jenison—Chevalier Brancia, Baron Gremp, Mr St: Genest, and Mr Lesseps the French Consul and his family, went yesterday down to Oranienbaum to dinner; embarked in the Evening, and sailed in the Night.

24. Called upon Mr Harris, and left with him a letter for Mr Hazard— Returned Mr Hochschild’s visit— He is at the Hotel de l’Europe— He told me that Mr Zea had arrived last Evening from the Emperor’s Head-Quarter’s; but knew nothing of his having gone to Moscow— Mr Harris however told me that, the Senate had yesterday received information that the Emperor had arrived at Moscow.— Mr Zea is received and acknowledged as the accredited Agent of the Spanish Government at Cadix. He saw the Emperor at one place, and Count Romanzoff at another— I called at Mr Bezerra’s, but he did not receive me— In the Evening, I rode out with the Ladies to Kammenoi-Ostrof, and walked home with Charles.

25. Morning visit from Mr Saltus and Mr Delprat— I dined with Charles at Mr Raimbert’s, and met there Mr Boucher, and another Gentleman, whom I did not know— Mr Raimbert mentioned that the Ratification of the Turkish Peace had arrived— On returning home I received a Notification from the Grand-Master of the Ceremonies, that a Te Deum will be celebrated to-morrow morning at the Cazan Church on this Event.— Dr Galloway was here in the Evening— There has been three days a rumour that the Emperor Alexander was gone to Moscow; but various motives are assigned for this movement— The Grand-Duchess Catherine on Wednesday last left this City for Tver or Novogorod— From the armies, nothing Official since this day week— The Ladies went to the Theatre, and on my return from Mr Raimbert’s I left Charles there— The rain deprived me of my walk.

26. At ten this morning, the hour appointed for the celebration of the Te Deum, for the Peace concluded with the Ottoman Porte, I went with Mr Smith to the Cazan Church, and we were there waiting upwards of two hours before the Empresses, with the two Grand-Dukes, Nicholas and Michael made their appearance— The Mass preceded the Te Deum, and they were each more than an hour in performing— It was about half past two when the services finished and we returned home— The Church was extremely crowded; but the only foreign Ministers present were Count Maistre the Chevalier Bezerra, Baron Blome and myself— I saw there, General Kutuzoff, who signed the Peace, and Count Liewen, late Russian Minister at Berlin— The Grand Master of the Ceremonies Narishkin, read me from the Russian, the hand-Bill issued last Evening, concerning the Military Operations; and dated the 9/21 of this Month.— The Commentaries upon the State of things were various. It was generally agreed that the French army, is wedged in between the first and second Russian Armies, and in an extremely dangerous position— Count Maistre said, if the Emperor Alexander was in such a position, we could not sleep, for anxiety. . . Mais. . . voila ce q’ue c’est. . . l’Etoile de cet homme. . . And what is strange: the private letters from the Officers in the Army are written in the finest spirits imaginable—gay as larks. . . wherever they go; the ladies and gentlemen of the vicinities go into the Cities with them, and make agreeable Society—and they have charming music &c. . . Mr Bezerra could hardly believe that the Emperor should have gone to Moscow— But he knew Count Romanzoff had been some time at Veliki-Luki; and General Pfhul was there too— General Pfhul had lost all his influence with the Emperor.— Mr Bezerra could not conceive neither how the French should have taken the Russian Magazines at Orsha. Why could not they have set fire to them?— Twenty days provisions for the whole army!— Very Strange!— In substance nothing is yet done— The two Russian armies appear to be near forming their junction; but whether they will be able to effect it, without separately giving Battle is still to be determined by the Event.— After dinner I rode out with the Ladies and Charles to Kammenoi-Ostrof— Left the Carriage to walk; but the rain obliged us to return to it— I read Sermons 1. and 2. Vol. 8 of the English Preacher— On Hypocrisy; and on the Terrors of Conscience— We found on our return home, Captain Boit, who spent a couple of hours with us— There was an Illumination at Night— Not very general. At the Church, General Wiesmitinoff, the Military Governor of St: Petersburg, performing the functions of the Minister of War, read before the Te Deum, a paper announcing the conclusion of the Peace with the Porte, at Bucharest— After the Te Deum, the Empresses, and Grand-Dukes went up and performed their prostrations, to the image of the Holy Virgin of Cazan, which they very devoutly kissed— General
Kutuzoff himself also, apparently had a private act of devotion of his own to perform for he went alone into the sanctuary— On my remarking it, Mr Bezerra, who seemed to think there was something of ridicule in the idea, ascribed the General’s movement to another Cause—

27. Captain Phelps, Master of a vessel from New-York, called the Maria Theresa, came to ask my assistance to obtain the admission, of his Cargo, which is yet in suspense, because he has no Certificates of Origin authenticated by a Russian Consul— I had a Visit from the Chevalier de Bray, who arrived yesterday from Wolmarshoff, the Seat of his father in Law, near Riga— The Chevalier did not find it convenient to go from Pernau or Hapsal, according to the permission he had received, and preferred coming here; where he finds it too late to go with his Colleagues; but where he will be provided with a vessel by this Government. He left Count Bose at Wolmarshoff, but he is coming back here to go with him— He has been to be betrothed to Miss Lise Löwenstern, Madame de Bray’s youngest Sister; but the marriage is to be postponed untill a more quiet time. General Pardo, has fallen sick on the road, in Livonia, and cannot now proceed— Mr Rayneval finally embarked with his wife at Riga; but in so small a vessel that he could not take his Carriage with him.— After dinner I walked in the Summer Garden’s, and took Charles with me from the Carriage at the gate. Returning home in the Evening I called to see Mr and Madam Bezerra, but they were not at home.

28. Captain Krusenstern called on me early this morning, for the purpose of recommending to me a Mr Neumann, a Professor, at the University of Dorpat, who is desirous of going to America— He said that this Gentleman had been much employed by Mr Speransky, but now in these troublous times wished to quit this Country, and go either to England, or the United-States, and in preference to the last. He strongly recommended him as a man of merit and abilities; and I assured the Captain that I should be happy to serve him— He is to call upon me himself— There are rumours, that the Empresses, are in two or three days to quit the City— This afternoon I rode out on the Wyburg road, and walked home from Kammenoi-Ostroff— Called upon the Chevalier de Bray, but he was abroad.

29. Captain Phelps was here again this morning, on the business of his Cargo, which is not admitted for want of Certificates of origin, executed by Russian Consuls— I promised him to speak concerning it to Mr Gourieff, the Minister of Commerce, which I accordingly did— I called on him by appointment at One O’Clock— Stated to him the Circumstances under which the ship Maria Theresa, had arrived— The difficulty with regard to the admission of her Cargo; and the importance to the parties interested that it should be decided upon as speedily as possible—the goods being already damaged, and daily perishing— He took the name of the ship; and promised immediate attention to it. I mentioned again the complaint and application from Mr Hazard, the American Consul at Archangel. He said he had already dispatched orders to the Custom-House there, to use the utmost expedition in the examination of the Papers produced for Vessels under American Colours, and that immediately after the examination they should be returned to their Captains or persons producing them— This I suppose is all that can be necessary for Mr Hazard, or that I can require. I spoke likewise of the wages due to the sailors of the vessels seized and confiscated for having come here, with forged American Papers, concerning which Mr Harris has made repeated applications to him— He said he had written to Mr Harris, that this was a matter of judicial resort to the tribunals, and not belonging to his Department— The Consul had however renewed his application, to which he should shortly send an answer— He had supposed at first that the Government might be willing to discharge from the forfeiture itself the wages due to the Seamen, but upon enquiry he found this was a thing that never had been asked for before— The vessel being seized and condemned as forfeited, it was impossible for the Government to assume upon itself the charges and expences which she had incurred in coming here, or the accounts and claims which might be brought against her. I said that the claims of the Sailors for their wages, were of a peculiar character— That by the maritime Law, which was part of the Law of Nations, the body of the ship was answerable for them— That they were in other Countries, in mine particularly in mine, and I presumed in this recoverable by a summary process, before the maritime or commercial tribunals— But that these seizures stood upon a different basis— They were ordered by a special Ordinance of the Emperor, and submitted to a special Commission appointed only for these cases— The remedy for the Sailors of resorting to the tribunals, was therefore taken from them; and when the Government seized the vessel to which they belonged, without having participated in the Offence for which she was taken, it seemed but just that the Government should take her charged with the debt due to them for wages, which was the easiest thing in the world to ascertain and adjust, and was by no means like a complicated account of expenses, which it
might be found inconvenient to settle— He said he could only repeat that this was an affair out of his department. He would answer Mr Harris’s last Note, and then the subject might still be liable to discussion diplomatically— For his part, he detested the whole thing; of seizure and confiscation— He wished it was entirely done away— But that was neither here nor there— So he found the law, and so he was bound to execute it— I observed that after learning the principle assumed by this Government, I was aware that my recourse was to another department; and that I had applied to him in this case only in consequence of the encouragement he had formerly given me, for such informal applications— He answered that he hoped I should continue to make them, whenever it might be in his power to serve me; and he should always be happy to prove to me as he had always wished to do, his disposition to accommodate my wishes. . . I asked him if the Peace with England was concluded?— He believed not— He was extremely anxious and impatient for it—for, said he, there can be no question now, but that we are at War with France, and having a common Enemy, it is highly desirable that we should have the benefit of co-operation— He said he was happy to see that the late measures in England, were of a tendency to remove the prospect of War, between that Country and the United States; in which sentiment I very cordially concurred.— On leaving him I called at the house of the Chevalier de Bray; but he was not at home— I then went and sat an hour with Mr Bezerra, whom I found with a lame foot—a touch of Gout, for having stood so long on the stone floor of the Cazan Church— No Rose without a Thorn— I asked him about the dispatches sent by Mr Zea—he it seems left them at Stockholm; not then intending to go to England himself— This Resolution he first took at Orebro; but the packets were left and did not go, untill the next Courier passed through— His last Courier too it seems was a swindler who has taken up money, and attempted to get much more on account of being his Courier, though not authorized to draw for a shilling— He had and shewed me french translations of the Emperor’s proclamation, at Polotzk, and of that issued here by the Holy Synod. Both have some remarkable features— He said it was strange, the Peace with England was not made; and it was a proof there had been no previous Understanding between the parties— I told him I thought that must be understood with some qualification— He said it had been universally supposed by all parties, that he had been charged with overtures from the British Ministers— He supposed few people would even now believe him, if he denied it— But he solemnly gave me his word of honour, (which he repeated more than once) the British Ministry had never opened their lips to him about this Country— He had not been however in this Country a fortnight before he found there were persons who said this and that as from the British Ministers to this Government, and who found means of conveying this and that in return— But all irresponsibly; and he believed all without adequate authority on either side— Merely officious meddlers— I think it probable this was really all the intercourse, before the discussions at Stockholm; between Mr Foster and General Van Suchtelen— He said he wondered the British Government had not a person here, as the Spaniards had Zea—with powers; and on the watch for the favourable moment. It was dangerous to lose so much time— We had much other conversation and upon various topics— Their dinner table was laid before I came home— A heavy thunder shower continuing at intervals from our dining hour untill near Midnight, detained us at home in the Evening. I had bathed and walked before Breakfast this morning. Had visits from Mr Woodward, and Mr Harris; who told me the Grand-Duke was gone to Moscow, at which the Empress Mother was displeased— There was a perfect harmony between Generals Bennigsen and Barclai de Tolli, and the Battle was hourly expected— The French were said to be at Smolensk, and the king of Naples had suddenly left the French army, to go and quell some disturbances in his own kingdom.

30. Captain Phelps called on me again this morning, and I informed him of the application I made yesterday concerning his affair to Mr Gourieff, and of that Minister’s promise that he would immediately give orders to have the business finished— I walked this morning before Breakfast to the Summer Gardens— After dinner I rode to the Apothecaries Island— The Ladies went to Kammenoi-Ostroff— I walked round the Botanical Garden; and thence home— The Ladies returned from a visit to Madame Bezerra, where they saw Madame Colombi— This Lady has been made a Countess, by the Spanish Government at Cadix— Don Francisco, a knight of the royal order of King Charles the third, and Mr Zea, Minister Plenipotentiary to this Court— She said there was now an Alliance between Russia, and Spain— They had also a great budget of good news arrived by a Courier this Evening from the army.— I read the remainder of the volume upon Comets, sent me by Judge Davis— The Lectures by Dr Winthrop, and the Essay by Mr Oliver, which I had never seen before, gave me some information; but Mr Oliver’s assertion in a Note that in the Winter of 1759–60 there was one Sunday morning at Boston, an instantaneous change in the temperature of the atmosphere, from Severe Cold to Summer heat, staggers my faith in his accuracy— I find Mr Bowditch’s Calculations, concerning the Comet of last year, agreeing very precisely with those of Mr Schubert here.

31. Mr Neumann, the Professor of Dorpat, of whom Captain Krusenstern had spoken to me, called on me this morning to make enquiries, respecting his purpose of going to America— His object would be, either to practice Law, or to go into some family as the Tutor of a Young Gentleman, finishing his Education— I mentioned to him the difficulties which he would probably encounter in both these pursuits— For the practice of the Law, the language— The Codes of the Country and forms of process different from those with which I supposed him acquainted; and the time which must pass before he could become a Citizen of the United States— There might be some means of obviating this last; examples of exception in favour of foreigners having occurred. For the project of becoming a Tutor, the manners of the Country— The Education of Children in the United States, partook of the nature of the Government— It was gregarious— In Schools, Academies, Colleges, and University— As the head of such an Institution, or a teacher connected with it, his prospect of success would be better than in that of obtaining a place of Governor to a single young man in a private family— He thanked me for the information, and for the opinions I had given him, which he saw were not encouraging to his object— He balanced he said between going to England or to America.— He should prefer the last if the prospects there should be equally favourable— He could yet stay here if he pleased; but his inclination was to go, and he had always wished to visit America— I told him if he finally concluded to go there, I would give him letters, and any other assistance in my power— Captain Hillard was here, for a Certificate upon his Passport which I gave him. After dinner we road out on the Wyburg Road and returned by Kammenoi-Ostrof— Walked with Catherine & Charles in the Botanic-Garden, and then home alone— I found Mr Lewis, who had a letter from Mr Connell at Gothenburg with late Accounts from America, reviving the apprehension of a War with England— English papers to the 10th: instt: with dates from New-York, to 13. June make it almost certain—to my great sorrow— I pray it may yet be avoided.— Mr Montreal was here this morning. No news from the Russian armies.

Day. As the Nights begin to be perceptible, and the weather to be warm, I find it practicable to rise earlier in the morning, and to observe more regularity in the distribution of time. But during almost the whole of this Month I have risen late— Seldom before seven; sometimes between eight and nine— I read and Journalize an hour or two untill Breakfast— Hear Charles read, pay or receive visits, and write from Breakfast untill 5 in the afternoon, when we dine— Soon after dinner I ride out of town, five or six Miles, and walk home— Come in between ten and eleven at Night.— Retire about midnight— I persevere in the attempt to teach Charles to read, in French and English— His progress in three months is scarcely perceptible.
